p: A particular virus serotype persisted in some geographic regions for several years, emerging periodically to cause epidemics, as herd immunity in the human population waned, and as new epidemic strains of virus emerged. This is supported by recent studies that have shown that a single serotype and genotype have remained dominant in a country causing periodic epidemics for as long as 20 years ( Gubler, 2014). It has also been documented that some virus subtypes persist in urban communities with “silent” transmission, causing mild nonspecific febrile illness not recognized as dengue ( Gubler et al., 1978, Yoon et al., 2012).
